Apparently, the BSD form imposes the word "Contributor". Do we want this?
Shouldn't the word "Contributor" be kept for people who do something listed at http://www.mozilla.org/contribute/?
At some point the word "member" was used to name "Joiners".

I am taking the liberty to make this bug "critical" since words that we use now are crucial. These are the words that people and media are going to use from the moment the program is officially launched.

Reproducible: Always

comments.text: How does the translation work? Would it be possible to hack the translating system in order to put the texts we want?
comments.raw_text: How does the translation work? Would it be possible to hack the translating system in order to put the texts we want?

comments.author: cnovak@mozilla.com
comments.text: Generally speaking on a page that processes secure transactions, we want to keep the hacking to a minimum. The translation of this field is generated by BSD's internal dictionaries.

comments.text:
I understand the concern. By "hacking the translating system", I just meant the displayed string. And I was considering more of a "soft hack". For instance, how hard would it be for them to create a fake local (Mozilla-English or something) in which we'd put the words we want?
It would mean more work for use, but at least a better control over the wording we want to use.
